item.description:
"Juror #9: It's eleven to one.

Juror #7: So, what do we do now?

#8: You're alone.

#3: I don't care if I'm alone or not! It's my right.

#8: It's your right.

#3: Well, what do you want from me?

#8: We want your arguments.

#3: I gave ya my arguments!

#8: We're not convinced! We want to hear them again. We have as much time as it takes.

#3:Everything... every single thing that came out in that courtroom, but I mean everything... says he's guilty"

12 Angry Men, by Reginald Rose.

 

 

 

Story Making III: An exploration of dialog

 

In a novel, a play, or a movie, what are great examples of dialog?

How by the right choice of words, can the writer so perfectly express a character's motivation, emotion, etc?  How does the writer approach the pacing, the rhythm, the musicality of the words she chooses?

 

How better to explore what makes great dialog then to try out some some scenes from plays and screenplays.  I'll provide copies of printed scenes we'll perform.  Bring your stage voices! Only sign up for this event if you think it would be fun to play a few characters in dialog scenes.

 

We'll have scenes to perform from William Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing, as well as more recent works.

 

Think of dialog scenes from stories or plays that you find vividly memorable for how they advanced the plot or brought a character to life for you.  What authors do you think of as great dialog writers? We'll discuss the examples people bring.

 

So come join the Inquisitve Minds Theater Troupe!

 

 

[Date subject to change]

 

 

"O villain! thou wilt be condemned into everlasting redemption for this."  -Dogberry, scene ii, Much Ado About Nothing
item.how_to_find_us: Meeting room is on the second floor.
item.name: "the play's the thing..."
